Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2010 06:19AM MaineCoonKitty wrote: I had a left side mastectomy and also experience pain at the edge of my rib cage if I poke around there.  I mentioned it to my oncologist and breast surgeon and they both agreed that it's likely a little scar tissue forming and possibly pulling on my rib cage and some nerves in there, but it's nothing to be alarmed about.  They both said once my body is fully healed from all the surgery and treatments, my body and the nerves in there will "re-set" and the pain will go away.
Posts.Title: A Pain in the Rib helena67 MaineCoonKitty

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 06:29AM - edited Apr 18, 2010 06:30AM by MaineCoonKitty I was a DD cup girl from the time I was a teenager on and hated the attention my big boobs got me.  I opted for a left side mastectomy and had a breast reduction done on the right side, down to a very small B cup.  Bye bye underwire bras!  I love being able to go without a bra at home and only having to wear a very light sports bra even in my clingiest work clothes.  I do wear a foob for work, but it's very small and very comfortable, but I have gone without one as well.  No big deal...if my staff is studying my chest, it's their problem, not mine. The best thing of all...being able to sleep on my stomach for the first time in years!  I really like being almost flat-chested and have no desire to do any recon at all.  No more blouses gaping at the buttons, no more sweaty, chaffing bras in the summer, no more lugging around huge hooters. You have to do what's best for you, but I LOVE being nearly flat chested.
Posts.Title: I'd rather be flat than fake...I think. Suzybelle robinlbe

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2010 01:01PM MaineCoonKitty wrote: I did not have much burning until about treatment 21, then it was a like a bad sunburn.  I just finished #33 (last 5 were boosts) this week and this week has been the worst.  I have some blisters and skin peeling, even though I've used aloe and Bag Balm religiously throughout the whole thing.  It's not horrible - just like a very bad sunburn - very ouchy and the blisters weep, then burst.  Today is the 3rd day without a treatment and the skin is heeling up nicely now.  I keep it slathered in Bag Balm and that seems to really speed the healing. Have faith...you CAN do it.
Posts.Title: questions about radiation icey Chicago1018

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 06:31AM MaineCoonKitty wrote: I was diagnosed with a malignant phyllodes tumor in my left breast in late April, 2009.  Because of the size of the tumor, I had a complete single mastectomy about 4 1/2 weeks ago and have done very well since then.  I have decided against reconstruction, but I'm 54 and that's a very different issue when you're only 30.  Phyllodes is a very rare cancer and most phyllodes are either benign or borderline.  There is a very good support group in the Rare Cancer Alliance website which is dedicated to phyllodes with women in your area who can probably refer you to someone who has experience with it.  There is a clinical study topic with a Dr. Barth at Dartmouth in New Hampshire, but Sloan-Kettering, the Mayo Clinic, the Cleveland Clinic and several other large teaching cancer hospitals also have breast specialists and oncologists that have experience with phyllodes, both benign and malignant.  Luckily, my own breast surgeon had experience with it because she was trained at The James Cancer Hospital at The Ohio State University here in Columbus, Ohio, which is one of the top 10 cancer research centers in the US.  She also contacted the Mayo Clinic to independently confirm my pathology reports and course of treatment with a world-class phyllodes specialist there. One thing that I can advise you from my own experience - don't sacrifice your life and your future peace of mind for a mere breast.  If your doctor is advising a mastectomy, then do it.  It may seem devastating at your age to lose a breast, but breasts are easily replaceable with reconstruction or very realistic fake boobs - or "foobs".    Your life, your future health, and your peace of mind are not.  Phyllodes is a different animal altogether from other types of breast tumors, benign and malignant with a higher rate of recurrence that does not respond well to either chemo or radiation.  I'm not trying to scare you, but you need the facts from women who have walked in your shoes to make an informed decision.  As one of those women, my best advice is to find a doctor you're comfortable with who has experience specifically with phyllodes tumors and follow his/her recommendations.  Come over to the Phyllodes section of the Rare Cancer Alliance Support Group and the women there will be glad to share their experiences and knowledge with you.  Many of them have done extensive research on their own and know more about the subject than a lot of doctors!
Posts.Title: phyllodes tumors syzygy1979 Athulita108

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 06:36AM - edited Jun 7, 2009 06:39AM by MaineCoonKitty Here's the direct link to the Phyllodes section of the Rare Cancer Alliance Support board: http://survivor-support.rare-cancer.org/forum/viewforum.php?f=114 You'll have to register and be approved by the moderator to read and post.

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2010 08:26AM MaineCoonKitty wrote: Yep...Gemzar was harder for me than Taxotere. I had 6 three week cycles, getting Taxotere with Gemzar on the 1st day, then Gemzar alone on days 8 and 15.  It made no sense to me that I felt relatively well when I got Tax and Gem together. but felt awful (like I had the flu) when I had Gemzar alone.  Then I had an "Ah HA!" moment.  When I got the Taxotere, they gave me all the pre-meds - Decadron, Pepsid, and lots of fluids - but when I got the Gemzar alone, all I got with it was saline!  So I talked to my onc about it and she agreed to try giving me the same pre-meds with the Gemzar to see if it made a difference.  It did, and from then on, I got the pre-meds every time.  Made a huge difference in how I felt.  If you're not getting pre-meds with Gemzar, or they may not be the right ones, talk to your onc about it.
Posts.Title: Feeling terrible after Gemzar Robin-Kaye PJB

Posts.Content: May 27, 2009 08:16AM MaineCoonKitty wrote: Livingood8: I had a high grade malignant Phyllodes tumor in my left breast and had a simple mastectomy just 3 wks ago.  I live pretty close to you in Ohio - Mt Vernon.  It came on pretty fast - within a few months, my left breast and the tumor that were removed weighed 22 lbs!  I'm currently hooked up to a wound vac and the wound is closing nicely, but I may still need a skin graft to "pretty up" the incision.  I got completely clear margins, even with that large of a tumor.  My breast surgeon and oncologist believe that my lymph nodes are not involved, just irritated and swollen from the infection and bleeding from the tumor and are receding on their own.  I'll have another CAT scan tomorrow to see if that's still the case, but the surgeon did not even feel the need to remove a sentinel node during my surgery.  Email me if you want the particulars about my surgeon and the details of my surgery.  The good news is that Phyllodes does not usually involve the lymph nodes and that's a good thing!

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2009 01:07PM MaineCoonKitty wrote: Yasmin- I also live in Central Ohio, Mt Vernon to be exact.  PM me if you want to compare drs. It's scary...I know.  I have a very rare form of bc - phyllodes tumor.  It's so rare that there is not much good recent data about how to treat it beyond mastectomy.  In the past, that was considered the only treatment.  But because my Onco team is very progressive and think outside the box, they presented my case to the local tumor board, as well as getting direction from a world-class expert in phyllodes from the Mayo Clinic. In preparation for that review, they did a new review of the available literature of this kind of cancer.  Guess what?  They found a new study from Europe that it is now thought that this kind of cancer could respond to chemo and radiation in a similar fashion to a form of sarcoma used in a clinical trial, since it is closely related to sarcoma.  So because of my score of 27, they offered the option to me of  6 rounds of Taxotere and Gemzar, followed by 4 weeks of daily radiation.  Now I have no lymph node involvement or evidence of disease anywhere else at the moment, so most women would say no chemo and no radiation because there's no real research that proves it will be of benefit to me at all.  But here's the thing......every new protocol of standard treatment had to start with that one person who some radical experimental treatment actually worked for, even though there was no proof it would. If I were in your shoes (and I am...kinda), at your age, I would hit this beast with everything I could and keep hitting it until it cried "uncle!"  My rationale for doing it is that even if it does nothing and my cancer recurrs somewhere down the road, I want to be have peace of mind that I did everything possible to fight it.  And if it keeps me cancer free for the rest of my life, then I'll know the 6 months of discomfort and the loss of a little bit of hair was worth it.
Posts.Title: 31 yrs. Old Struggling to decide on Chemo yasminv1 yasminv1

Dexy, Pepsid amd Benadryl as my pre-meds and I've never had to take even one of my Compazine after treatment.  So far, after 5 cycles, I have not had even one day of nausea.  Either I am very lucky or I have a cast iron stomach!
Posts.Title: Ativan/Compazine instead of Emend? Ang7 kayakgirl

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2009 11:32AM MaineCoonKitty wrote: No recon of any kind for me.  I lugged around D and DD's from the time I was 14 and hated every minute of the catcalls and underwire bras that were necessary to support those hooters.  I could not wait to be free of all that.  I only had a left-side mastectomy. but begged my surgeon to take the other healthy one too, but she wouldn't.  So I had it reduced down to a small B.  Most of the time, I don't even have to wear a bra at all because I'm so nearly flat that I don't wear the foob.  For work and for dress-up clothes, I wear either a sports bra or a very small size B and that enough to keep the foob in place and it give me plenty of support for the real boob. I LOVE doing all the things that big boobs restricted me from doing for so many years - sleeping on my stomach, not having to wear a bra 24/7, being able to wear halter tops, tank tops, and pretty blouses that button up the front, running, and finding bathing suits that don't need an underwire for support.  It's a personal decision for every woman, but there's no way I would ever go back to not being able to see my feet in the shower!
Posts.Title: need more support for my decision MicheleS melissa-5-19

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2010 09:10AM MaineCoonKitty wrote: I had the jelly legs, beginning with taxotere cycle #3 and also developed neuropathy in my left foot, beginning with cycle #4.  I'm about 8 weeks out from my last chemo and just finished 33 rad treatments yesterday.  Just in the last week or so, I've definitely noticed a big improvement, especially in the foot pain.  As Marie45 said, I've been unable to wear any shoes with even the slightest heel and can only wear heavily padded comfort type shoes like SAS or Rockport.  I  walk every day and that seems to have helped immensely with the weak legs.  I started out just pushing myself to walk a little bit more every day, up and down the stairs inside, then moved outside for 10 minutes at a time, several times a day.  I used to be a 3 mile a day walker, so I'm gradually building back up slowly.  It does get better for most people - it just takes some time.

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2009 10:06AM MaineCoonKitty wrote: Congrats on the end of your chemo!  I have one more cycle of Taxotere and Gemzar out of 6, so I won't be done until the new year, but I cross out every day that I have left and give myself a treat at the end of every week.  I'll have a month off then will start 4-6 weeks of rads in Feb and should be done with everything by Easter!  Every day is a small victory.
Posts.Title: very very happy guardian blondie45

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 04:06PM MaineCoonKitty wrote: I'm on a Taxotere/Gemzar combo.  I get Taxotere and Gemzar both on Day 1, then Gemzar alone on days 8 and 15.  On the Tax/Gemzar day, I get a steroid, Benadryl, and another anti-emetic first by IV, then the Gemzar and finally the Taxotere.  The Benadryl makes me sleepy, but I have had no side effects from the either the Taxotere or the Gemzar.  On the Gemzar days, I only get the Benadryl, but no other anti-emetic, so I have to conclude that the Gemzar is less likely to cause side effects than the Tax.  My hair loss is from the Tax, although I have heard that Gemzar also causes hair loss.  My hair thinned to about 1/3 of its usual volume, but I'm not completely bald.  I did shave it down and now I have colorless fuzz all over my head, which is growing even though I'm just beginning the 3rd of my 6 cycles. The weeks I get Gemzar alone are really good weeks.  I have no side effects of any kind - no metallic taste, no problems with my nails, good appetite, no fatigue.  I have heard that Gemzar is very well tolerated by most people and that seems to be the case with me, although I seem to be tolerating the much more toxic Taxotere equally well. I have heard very good things about the success with Gemzar.  This is my first go-around with chemo, but I had a very rare type of BC that is not known to respond well to chemo - phyllodes tumor.  My onc team is using me as a guinea pig in treating phyllodes with chemo and rads, since I had such a large tumor that grew very quickly.  She choose Gemzar because of the good things she is seeing in using it to treat other types of cancer. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Gemzar?? BarbJ MaineCoonKitty

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 02:41PM MaineCoonKitty wrote: You're very welcome!  Yep...I'm still doing quite well on the taxotere and gemzar and am now about 1/2 way through the chemo.  YAY! Yes..I do have a Maine Coon.  He's 3 yrs old and weighs 32 lbs!  His name is Highlander's Rocky Road Sundae - Rocky, for short.  He's my first Maine Coon and my "little" buddy.  They truly are a dog in a cat suit!  He walks on a leash, loves to swim and demands to play fetch. I'm thinking about getting him a sister.  We have another cat, a plain old domestic shorthair who adopted us, but Rocky likes to play rough and his "brother" is only 9 lbs.  We think he needs another cat of the same size to play with.
Posts.Title: Gemzar?? BarbJ MaineCoonKitty

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 03:54PM MaineCoonKitty wrote: I had a simple mastectomy on the left side on May 1st that removed a whooper of a malignant Phyllodes tumor along with an infected breast that weighed a grand total of 22 lbs.  The surgical wound could not be closed and I woke up with a wound vac pump attached, which I still have, 8 wks later.  The wound has shrunk down from 28 cm x 20 cm to 8.5 x 3.5 cm as of today, with the help of that vac pump. Sometime in the next couple of weeks, I'll have a skin graft to close it completely. Despite all that, what surprised me most was how much better I felt the minute I woke up from surgery with that monstrosity gone.  I felt wonderful - no nausea, no vomiting, no pain, no fog at all - from the moment I woke up in the recovery room.  I could put my arm above my head right away and by 4 hrs after my surgery, was up and walking the halls of the hospital with my IV pole and vac pump in tow.  The most uncomfortable part for me were the dressing changes because of the open wound site and the spongy dressing, covered by a plastic film that seals the vacuum over the wound.  The dressing actually debrides the wound and when it is pulled off, it pulls the top layer of the new tissue with it on purpose, to stimulate new collagen to form and seal off the wound.  Yow!  But even that pain was controlled with meds and the dressing is only changed 3 times a week.  Ladies....don't be afraid of the mastectomy.  I think it's actually less painful than many lumpectomies because all the tissue and nerves are removed.  Compared to a hysterectomy due to large fibroids that left me a scar that runs from my pubic bone to up above my navel, the mastectomy was a piece of cake!  You'll be fine and just like me, I bet you won't miss the girl or girls anymore than I do!  After being a DD cup for years, then dealing with the " Mongo Boob from Hell" for several months, it's a refreshing RELIEF to go braless or just wear a stretchy sports bra and be able to sleep comfortably.
Posts.Title: Things that surprised me after mastectomy Lursa5 Ariom

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2010 10:42AM MaineCoonKitty wrote: I had a left side mast and would have gone with a bilateral if my surgeon would have done it.  She wouldn't because the right one was perfectly healthy and the type of BC I had (phyllodes tumor) is rarely found in both breasts.  Since I didn't want any reconstruction, I had my right healthy one reduced down from a DD to a very small B and am quite happy with it all now.
Posts.Title: Calling all uni-mast ladies 1marmalade1 Brendatrue

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2009 02:58PM MaineCoonKitty wrote: I had my port put in on Tuesday, July 14th, on the right side.  I also had a left side skin graft to cover the mastectomy wound and a right side breast reduction done at the same time.  There is zero pain at the skin graft site and more soreness than real pain on the right side at the port site.  I suspect that the soreness is more from the swelling from the breast reduction than from the port.  I do have the shoulder soreness, but it's tolerable with a little Percocet.  I have a pretty high pain tolerance, but really, it's not bad at all.  I don't expect to be running or playing tennis this week, but really ladies, don't fear the port - it's not that bad - sore, more than painful, at least for me.
Posts.Title: Port-a Cath pain? TinaLee Kicks

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2009 10:24AM MaineCoonKitty wrote: An update today (port installation plus 4 days): Saw the plastic surgeon yesterday for the follow-up visit on the skin graft and rt side breast reduction.  Will see the breast surgeon on Wed for the port install follow-up.  The port was by far the most sore of all of the procedures, but 4 days later, even the mild soreness is now gone from my shoulder.  I was on Percocet and Vicodene for about 24 hrs post surgery, Advil for another 12 and for the last 24 hrs, no pain meds needed at all.  Slept like a baby for the last three days and walked a mile yesterday and 2 miles this morning with no pain or fatigue.  Have full range of motion in both arms and shoulders and am pretty much back to my normal routine, with the exception of lifting things heavier than 5 lbs, which greatly upsets my 30 lb Maine Coon buddy! I was a little afraid of the port install after seeing the problems that so many of you have had with it, but it was truly very tolerable and will prove to be a blessing in the long run when my chemo starts.  No more digging around for a "good" vein for me, just plug the little sucker in and let's roll!  Honestly...a couple days of soreness was very doable.  I might be one of the luckier ones with so little pain, but I've had more painful dental appointments than this latest round of surgery. Have faith, ladies...it's not bad and you've already proven that you're a tough bunch just by making the decision to fight this monster with everything you have. Rock on, BC sistahs!
Posts.Title: Port-a Cath pain? TinaLee Kicks

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2010 02:45PM MaineCoonKitty wrote: My GP referred me to and I saw the surgeon first. She is my "team" leader who coordinates every facet of my treatmentwith the other dr's.  My team consists of my breast surgeon, plastic surgeon, oncologist, radiation oncologist, endocrinologist, and GP.  I love the team concept and it's been wonderful having someone like my breast surgeon running interference for me and I always feel like she's my advocate when it come to getting appointments scheduled and tests run.  When I was having port problems, she was the one who the oncology nurses called for help (my port line became kinked when they got over-zealous pushing hard trying to access it and my chest muscles underneath it swelled). It was also much easier and less stressful for me to get referred to the other specialists that she had worked with in the past because I trust her judgement and knew she would refer me to the very best other doctors.  And she did.......I love my entire team and trust their judgement, knowing that they are all looking out for my best interests and checking and re-checking each others' work constantly.  That makes me feel very confident that I'm getting expert care from many experts who work together like clockwork.

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2009 11:57AM MaineCoonKitty wrote: I had it too.  Use 3% hydrogen peroxide on a cotton ball and rub it all over your head twice a day.  Let it air dry.  It should dry up the pustules in a couple of days. I also found that washing my head with Dial soap twice a day, then rubbing on the hydrogen peroxide  really helped dry up the infection quickly.  Any anti-bacterial soap should work fine.
